Responsabilita' di studi e ricerche scie.content: Sociologo ricercatore. ASL 10 Firenze - Centro Studi, Documentazione e Ricerca Tossicodipendenze e Aids (CeSDA). I worked for approximately one year as a sociologist at the Centre for the Study, Documentation, and Research on Drugs Addiction and Aids / Health Public Centre (ASL 10 Firenze). At CeSDA, I edited reports, prepared press releases, organized conferences, and conducted research on the social phenomenon of AIDS. I then advised and supervised undergraduates’ research, and participated in AIDS information and prevention projects in local high schools.

Sociologo - Policy Evaluator. Comune di Firenze - Ufficio Tempi e Spazi della Citta'. I was responsible for the monitoring and evaluation of public projects on the rational use of time and space in the city of Florence. The research findings were published in 2001.

Specifiche esperienze professionali cara.content: Researcher - Department of Sociology, University of Florence. Before moving to the United States, I worked for several years with temporary contracts at the Department of Sociology (University of Florence). Shortly after my graduation in February 1993, I started working as a researcher at the Department of Sociology of the Faculty of Social and Political Sciences (University of Florence). During that period, I further developed my knowledge of and expertise in qualitative research methods (in-depth interviews, ethnographic work, focus group, visual sociology, etc.) as well as my skills in coaching other junior researchers and supervising their work. At the Department of Sociology I also taught a range of classes and seminars on several topic areas: Sociology of Family; Sociology of Deviance; Sociology of Health and Illness.

Research Associate, Department of Sociology, University of Florence. EU COMPARATIVE RESEARCH PROJECT – HPSE-CT-1999-00010. A three-year European research project involving Finland, France, Portugal, Italy and the UK and funded under the Key Action "Improving the Socio-Economic Knowledge Base" of FP5. Citizen and governance in a Knowledge-based society. Full title: New Kinds of Families, New Kinds of Social Care: Shaping Multi-dimensional European Policies for Informal and Formal Care. EU funding: €2.000.000

Teaching Assistant , Department of Sociology, University of Pennsylvania (US) Between 2004 and 2006, I lead weekly seminars and courses and acted as a tutor for undergraduate students. Among the courses I taught, 1) SOC001-201/2 Introduction to Sociology, with Prof. Richard Gelles; 2) SOC004-404/5 The Family, with Prof. Frank Furstenberg; 3) SOC100-401 Introduction to Sociological Research, with Prof. Kristen Harknett.

Research Associate, Research Institute for Health and Social Change (RIHSC), Manchester Metropolitan University (MMU), UK. At Manchester Metropolitan University, I worked as a Research Associate at the Research Institute for Health and Social Change (RIHSC) on a project called ‘Smart Distress Monitor’ (SDM). My activities and responsibilities included: working collaboratively with and coordinating the research team, the steering group of older/disabled people, the team of technologists and other key stakeholders in the research; taking an active part in the academic life; writing and submitting manuscripts for publication in peer reviewed journals; liaising closely and collaborating with colleagues on areas of shared research interest. During my research activity at MMU, I have also taught as a visiting lecturer for BA, MA and PhD level courses at various institutes: the Research Institute for Health and Social Change; the Faculty of Health, Social Care and Education; and the Department of Social Work and Social Change.

Lecturer in Sociology, Department of Social and Political Science, University of Chester (UK). I joined the Department of Social and Political Science in September 2011, having previously worked at the University of Florence (Italy), the University of Pennsylvania (USA) and Manchester Metropolitan University (UK).

Associate Professor (Senior Lecturer), University of Chester (UK) Currently, I am a Senior Lecturer at the University of Chester, where I teach Sociology courses at the Department of Social and Political Science. I supervise 3 PhD students and 12 dissertation students. My research interests include the Sociology of Emotions; Relationships, Intimacies and Families; Care and the Ethics of care; Cultural Citizenship and Social Change; Innovative Qualitative Methods. I am currently working on a ESRC project on the EU refugee crisis. The project aims to overcome conventional approaches to migration, citizenship and social inclusion merely based on economic, political, static and normative interpretations of the reality. The project's general goal is providing a critical understanding of major social and cultural changes involving people’s experiences and ideas of migration, citizenship and care and identifying the conditions under which such changes become a resource and can be seen as such. I then work on a book publication which is aimed to: 1) rethinking Care through more inclusive approaches and getting closer to its complex nature and less visible implications; and 2) shedding light on the emotion-based, interactional and anti-assimilationist model of social inclusion represented by same-sex parents (Palgrave Macmillan, forthcoming: 2017).

Ricercatore Associato (Research Associate). Smart Distress Monitor Project. Research Institute for Health and Social Change (RIHSC), Manchester Metropolitan University (UK), Technology Strategy Board and Infrared Integrated Systems Limited (£804,725). The ‘Smart Distress Monitor Project’ was aimed to analyse the sociological and psychological implications of new care related technology within the context of UK policy concerning independent and safe ageing at home. The 3-year project was based on an innovative partnership between university, industry and Technology Strategy Board.
